head.title: Did Global Warming Cause Red River Flood?

hedline.hl1: Did Global Warming Cause Red River Flood?

abstract.p: Kalee Kreider letter contends that winter storms responsible for disastrous Red River flood are consistent with scientific modeling of effects of climatic changes due to growing use of fossil fuels

block.p: You are correct to point out that the flooding of the Red River in North Dakota is an event that occurs once every 500 years (''No Ordinary Disaster,'' editorial, April 24). Overlooked in your editorial, however, is that although no single flood or storm can as yet be tied to global warming, an increase in the frequency of flooding is consistent with the scientific modeling on the impacts of climate change.

You are correct to point out that the flooding of the Red River in North Dakota is an event that occurs once every 500 years (''No Ordinary Disaster,'' editorial, April 24). Overlooked in your editorial, however, is that although no single flood or storm can as yet be tied to global warming, an increase in the frequency of flooding is consistent with the scientific modeling on the impacts of climate change.

Burning fossil fuels (coal, oil and gas) causes global warming and climate change. If our current energy policies continue unabated, 1-in-500-year events like the Red River flood could become more frequent, endangering human health and the environment.

Although you are correct in asking whether better flood prediction is needed, you should also ask why the Clinton Administration has taken virtually no policy steps to stop global warming, an underlying threat. These steps would include stopping new oil development, shifting subsidies from fossil fuels to clean, renewable energy and pushing for early action by 2005 in international negotiations for a legally binding treaty on climate change.
Another place to start would be to use Federal relief funds earmarked to rebuild the flooded areas so that they will rely on renewable sources of energy rather than on fossil fuels.
KALEE KREIDER Dir., Greenpeace Climate Campaign Washington, April 26, 1997
